title: Protocol for sodium depletion and measurement of sodium appetite in mice
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Sodium depletion
Timing: 24 h
This step will use furosemide to induce diuresis. Mice are then allowed to rehydrate and given access to sodium-deficient diets for 24 h. This protocol should induce sodium appetite in mice, while minimally affecting thirst or hunger.
Note: The time of sodium deprivation may need to be altered according to the study.
Weigh each mouse.
Note: We typically perform this step at 19:30 (ZG 12.5).
Provide a fresh cage with a clean lid.
If a researcher chooses to replace bedding in the home cage, ensure that cage lids do not have any chow encrusted on them (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).

Figure 2. Cleaning lids and valves
(A) Chow encrusted on the lid of the home cage.
(B) Rust formation inside the Lixit valve.
(C) Aluminium foil coated in sodium chloride.
(D) Scraping the inside of the Lixit valve with aluminium foil and sodium chloride.
(E) Discolouration of sodium chloride as rust is removed from the Lixit valve.
(F) Lixit valve with rust removed.
Wipe down cage lids with a water dampened paper towel to remove encrusted chow.
Note: It is recommended to provide a fresh cage. Either way, the protocol should be adapted to follow the local guidance from animal facilities.
Critical: The two previous steps ensure that remaining chow hidden inside the bedding or encrusted on the lid are removed and prevented from being used as a source of sodium.
Remove the 300 mM NaCl solution containing drinking tube from the home cage.
Inject mice subcutaneously with 50 mg/kg of furosemide (10 mg/mL) in a 1 mL syringe with a 26G needle.
Volume of furosemide to be injected can be calculated by mouse weight in grams × 5 μL.
Replace food from the home cage with sodium-deficient diet.

Clean the plastic part of the volumetric drinking tubes by scrubbing them gently under distilled water.
If necessary, remove rust from valves (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
Twist a piece of aluminium foil into a shape that can fit inside the valve.
Dip the aluminium foil into water and then into sodium chloride to coat the foil in sodium chloride (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C).
Scrub the insides of the valve with the sodium chloride-coated aluminium foil; sodium chloride will become discoloured as rust comes off the valves. Remove all rust from the inside of the valves (Figures 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]D–2F).
Soak the valves under copious amounts of distilled water to remove all traces of sodium.
Dry valves.
Fill the volumetric drinking tube with small amount of water and assemble with dried valve. Ensure the valve of the water tube is flowing properly by pressing on it. Fill the remaining water drinking tube with water and measure the volume.
Two-bottle assay
Timing: 4 h
This step will measure sodium appetite in the sodium-depleted mice.
23 h and 15 min later; weigh mice and remove distilled water from home cages.
Weigh mice. Mice should have decreased body weight.
Measure water intake. Mice typically drink at least 3 mL of water during this period.
Pharmacological manipulations can be performed at this step if required.
Note: We typically perform this step at 18:45 (ZG 11.75). For pharmacological experiments, this time may need to be adjusted accordingly for different drugs.
Clean the insides of the plastic tubes of the water-containing volumetric drinking tubes, by scrubbing gently under distilled water.
Fill volumetric drinking tubes with distilled water and sodium chloride solutions.
Ensure that all air bubbles are removed from the inside of the valves by tapping on them lightly.
Press on the Lixit valve lever to ensure that liquid flows from the valve.

Drain out any remaining liquid inside the valves with a dry paper towel (Figures 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A and 3B).
Critical: Liquid remaining inside the valves can substantially alter measurements, leading to inconsistent results.
Backfill the volumetric drinking tubes to full capacity using a 30 mL syringe with a 21G needle.
Note: We perform steps 11 and 12 away from mice, in a different room, to avoid disturbing them.
At 24 h after sodium depletion, replace both distilled water and sodium chloride solution containing volumetric drinking tubes back to the home cage of mice.
Measure water and sodium chloride intake every hour for 4 h.
Note: The duration of the test and frequency of measurements may need to be adjusted according to the study. We have found that a 4-hour assay is sufficient to measure elevated sodium intake in mice (Park et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]), but other investigators also have used variable time intervals from as short as 1–2 h to as long as 6–24 h (Jarvie and Palmiter, 2017[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]; Matusda et al., 2017[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]; Resch et al., 2017[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]; Rowland and Morian, 1999[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9]; Ryan et al., 2017[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11]).
